detailPageTitle.pageDescription: Optional overview sub heading description for the vent detail page content.

richText.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"value":"More than 80 percent of people charged with felonies cannot afford a private lawyer and often must rely on under-resourced public defenders, contract attorneys, or court-appointed counsel. States must fulfill their Sixth Amendment obligations and build a well-financed, state- administered system of indigent defense","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Aliquet posuere imperdiet nibh dictum per hendrerit laoreet. Fames consequat sit ullamcorper a penatibus adipiscing neque dictum nec condimentum eget neque non vitae posuere posuere. Taciti parturient magna enim consequat nibh elit parturient blandit hac ridiculus suspendisse condimentum cras a nunc.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"unordered-list","content":[{"nodeType":"list-item","content":[{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Build statewide “right to counsel” services with sufficient funding to ensure that public defenders have manageable caseloads and resources not only for investigators, experts, and language access services, but also for early pretrial representation and “holistic defense” practices. At the federal level, support these efforts by substantially increasing state grants.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"list-item","content":[{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Ensure funding and salary parity between public defenders and prosecutors.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"list-item","content":[{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Authorize the Department of Justice to sue jurisdictions that do not meet their Sixth Amendment obligations, such as by violating caseload limits or attorney independence, and require that states certify compliance with the Sixth Amendment to receive federal grants.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"list-item","content":[{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Abolish fees for public defenders and create fair, transparent frameworks for determining indigence.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"list-item","content":[{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Provide significant grants to states, provided that they conform their public defense systems to meet core principles set forth in the State Policy Priorities in the full platform. Place data collection contingencies on states receiving funding to incentivize robust data collection and reporting; in addition, require states to produce data that are disaggregated by people’s demographics and that specify how much time was dedicated to each person’s case. The funding should provide resources for building a robust, independent, and statewide “right to counsel” system.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"list-item","content":[{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Create a federal Center for Defense Services that provides technical assistance, support, and oversight for state public defense services.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

subPages.title: Plank 11: Ease legal challenges to address racial inequity and abolish slavery in prisons

pageListingInfo.title: Ease legal challenges to address racial inequity and abolish slavery in prisons

description.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"We must end the practice of slavery in jails and prisons while making it easier to challenge racially disparate policies in court. ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

detailPageTitle.pageHeadline: Abolish labor abuses, unpaid labor in prisons, and racial injustices

richText.raw: {"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"heading-3","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"A just society cannot exist when its most marginalized members are forced to perform unpaid or extremely underpaid labor for large corporations and governments. ","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}]},{"nodeType":"paragraph","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"The 13th Amendment, ratified in 1865, says: “Neither slavery nor involuntary servitude, ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"except as a punishment for crime whereof the party shall have been duly convicted","marks":[{"type":"italic"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":", shall exist within the United States, or any place subject to their jurisdiction.” The italicized phrase, known as the “exception clause,” has contributed to a prison-industrial complex that incarcerates Black people at five times the rate of White people, while profiting from their unpaid and/or underpaid labor. ","marks":[],"data":{}}]},{"nodeType":"paragraph","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"After passage of the 13th Amendment, Black Codes in the South created offenses that were intentionally vague, sending more Black people to prison than ever before. At the same time, many states put people in prison to work through the brutal and inhumane practice known as “convict-leasing” — a practice that allowed White plantation owners and industrialists to “lease” people in prison to work for them (against their will and for no pay) decades after the end of the Civil War. States also benefited from this free labor by forcing people to work on “chain gangs” building roads and growing crops on prison farms. This practice continues in various forms today.","marks":[],"data":{}}]},{"nodeType":"paragraph","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"What’s more, decisions in other areas have made equity-based challenges to exploitative, racialized practices difficult. Impossibly high bars to legal challenges, like the failure to consider “disparate impact” an acceptable basis for 14th Amendment Equal Protection Clause claims, has foreclosed legal challenges that could help combat racial injustice. We must end the practice of slavery in jails and prisons while making it easier to challenge racially disparate policies in court.","marks":[],"data":{}}]}]}

content.raw: {"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"heading-4","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Support a constitutional amendment that would eliminate the “exception clause” of the 13th Amendment, which continues to allow involuntary servitude in U.S. prisons and jails.","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

{"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"heading-4","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Support the establishment of a federal commission to study and develop reparation proposals for African Americans, including legislation like H.R. 40, the Commission to Study and Develop Reparation Proposals for African Americans Act.","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

{"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"heading-4","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Repeal the Prison Litigation Reform Act of 1996 and the Antiterrorism and Effective Death Penalty Act of 1996 and completely abolish qualified immunity.","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

promo1.title: Support the children of incarcerated parents

text.raw: {"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"We must create a world where children with an incarcerated parent are provided with adequate community-based supports and families can remain together.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

promo2.title: End inhumane conditions in jails and prisons in the United States

text.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"We must radically reduce prison and jail populations while creating a new system premised on healing, accountability, rehabilitation, and respect for basic human rights.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

slides.title: Demand dignity and human rights for all.

text.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Black people are five times more likely to be incarcerated than White people.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}
